Award.AwardTitle: Coordination-Driven self-Assembly: Multi-Component and Photophysical Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Peter J. Stang of the University of Utah investigates coordination-driven self-assembly of 2D metallacycles and 3D metallacages. Specifically, heterligated Pt-complexes, involving carboxylate and pyridyl ligands, will be studied that allow the formation of a greater variety and more complex supramolecular assemblies. Multi-component self-assembly, as well as the interconversion of homoligated pyridyl architectures with heteroligated systems, will be examined. The use of flexible ligands and heteroligated, flexible multi-component assemblies will be investigated.

This research will advance our fundamental understanding of how simple molecules spontaneously self-assemble into complex nanoscale systems. This work could have significant impact upon nanoscience and nanotechnology and, in particular, future "bottom up" manufacturing. It may also provide new materials with novel properties and functions such as sensors, catalysts, etc. of importance in the chemical industry. The broader impact also involves training postdoctoral researchers and graduate and undergraduate students in supramolecular self-assembly. These researchers will also be mentored in the dissemination of research results via presentations at major conferences and publications in premier peer reviewed, scientific journals.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly is nature's way of making complex molecules of relevance in every day life. We have imitated nature by using self-assembly to make new compounds of potential significance for the preparation of devices for sensing, energy storage and other applications. We have demonstrated that some of our self-assembled cyclic compounds may be used for explosives sensing via aggregation induced emission.  We have also prepared and characterized novel polymers with unique properties. We have studied the process of self-assembly itself by examining rearrangements in the formation of our cyclic and cage compounds. We have also been able to add useful functional groups to these cyclic and cage complexes.  We further prepared and characterized several molecular cages for possible targeted drug delivery. Preliminary biological testing indicate that several of our compounds have antitumor activity. Many of our compounds emit in the visible region and may be used for imaging, including as contrast agents for cell imaging.

We have examined the host-guest interactions of our systems.  We have studied dye-sensitized solar cells prepared via self-assembled Pt(II) metallacages. We have advanced none-biological self-assembly by developing multi-component processes based upon the directional bonding approach. All of our results are published in premier peer reviewed scientific journals, including a recent Accounts of Chemical Research article

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2016
Modified by: Peter J Stang
